RaptorNest.name: Raptor Nest
RaptorNest.strategy: While fragile compared to larger dinos, its speed and critical bleed damage make it lethal when used strategically. Place near path bends to maximize time on target.
RaptorNest.lore: These nimble predators once roamed the volcanic plains of Crater Delta, hunting in coordinated packs. Now, outfitted with bone-plated armor and sharpened obsidian claws, they've been trained for defensive warfare. Their nest eggs are actually incubation chambers for rapid deployment.
RaptorNest.funFact: Raptors have been observed playing a primitive form of soccer with rounded stones during their downtime. The current champion is a raptor named 'Bitey McBiteface'.

Protoceratops.name: Protoceratops
Protoceratops.strategy: Cheap frontliner that buys time. Use near corners to repeatedly stagger fast enemies so other towers can finish them.
Protoceratops.lore: Small but stubborn, the Protoceratops forms protective circles and rams intruders with surprising force.
Protoceratops.funFact: Handlers use scratch posts to keep their head shields polished and morale high.

Iguanodon.name: Iguanodon
Iguanodon.special: Thumb-spike spear that prioritizes nearest target
Iguanodon.strategy: Solid single-target ranged damage early on. Pairs well with slows and knockbacks.
Iguanodon.lore: With powerful forelimbs and iconic thumb spikes, Iguanodons hurl sharpened stakes with practiced accuracy.
Iguanodon.funFact: Their favorite enrichment is spearing watermelons at 20 paces.

Triceratops.name: Triceratops
Triceratops.special: Rush attack with stun (0.8s) and knockback (60px)
Triceratops.strategy: Excellent crowd control tower. The knockback can buy precious time and even push enemies back into range of other towers. Position at chokepoints for maximum effectiveness.
Triceratops.lore: The mighty Triceratops served as living battering rams in the ancient Saurian Wars. Their reinforced skull plates can generate enough force to derail a steam locomotive. Veterans bear scars from countless charges, each one a badge of honor.
Triceratops.funFact: Despite their fearsome appearance, Triceratops are vegetarians who have developed a peculiar fondness for imported Belgian waffles (when not in combat).

Brachiosaurus.name: Brachiosaurus
Brachiosaurus.special: 40% slow aura, light damage over time
Brachiosaurus.strategy: The ultimate support tower. Its massive canopy creates a slowing field that makes enemies vulnerable to other towers. Synergizes perfectly with high-damage towers.
Brachiosaurus.lore: These gentle giants were bio-engineered with symbiotic vine colonies that secrete paralytic spores. The tallest recorded Brachiosaurus, named 'Skyscraper', could peer over a four-story building. Their presence alone demoralizes enemy forces.
Brachiosaurus.funFact: Brachiosaurus towers double as weather stations - their long necks can accurately predict rain 3 days in advance by sensing atmospheric pressure changes.

Maiasaura.name: Maiasaura
Maiasaura.strategy: Anchor her near high-DPS towers to accelerate their attacks. Place just behind chokepoints; stacks well with slows and pierce lines. Multiple Maiasaura do not stack additivelyâ€”only the strongest aura applies.
Maiasaura.lore: The 'good mother lizard' watches over the herd. Handler drums cue a rhythmic heartbeat that syncs nearby dinosaurs into a relentless tempo, hastening their strikes.
Maiasaura.funFact: Handlers leave fruit garlands by her nest. She always eats the blueberries first.

Dilophosaurus.name: Dilophosaurus
Dilophosaurus.strategy: Area denial specialist. The lingering acid pools create kill zones that persist even between waves. Stack multiple Dilophosaurus for overlapping acid fields.
Dilophosaurus.lore: Modified with enlarged venom sacs harvested from prehistoric swamp dwellers, these creatures can project corrosive bile over impressive distances. The distinctive frill serves as both intimidation display and targeting array.
Dilophosaurus.funFact: Dilophosaurus towers have won three consecutive years in the annual 'Dino's Got Talent' competition with their synchronized spitting routine set to classical music.

Stegosaurus.name: Stegosaurus
Stegosaurus.strategy: Devastating against clustered enemies. Position along straight path sections where enemies bunch up. The pierce effect makes it incredibly cost-effective against swarms.
Stegosaurus.lore: The iconic back plates aren't just for show - they're launch platforms for volleys of detachable tail spikes. Each spike is grown from a special calcium deposit that regenerates within hours. Warriors paint their plates before battle.
Stegosaurus.funFact: A Stegosaurus named 'Spike Lee' holds the record for most enemies defeated with a single spike: 7 (it ricocheted off a rock).

Stonklodon.name: Stonklodon
Stonklodon.strategy: Essential for long-term economy. Place early to maximize returns. Multiple Stonklodons compound your income exponentially. The backbone of any greedy strategy.
Stonklodon.lore: These peculiar creatures evolved to digest precious metals, which they excrete as perfectly minted coins. Originally discovered in the abandoned gold mines of the Crystal Caverns, they've been domesticated as living treasuries.
Stonklodon.funFact: Stonklodons are compulsive hoarders and have been known to steal shiny objects from handlers. One famously stole the Colonel's monocle and refused to return it for a week.

TRex.name: T-Rex
TRex.special: Intimidation roar stuns nearby enemies (0.6s in 80px radius)
TRex.strategy: The apex predator. Its massive bite damage can eliminate tough enemies instantly, while the fear aura provides crowd control. Worth saving up for.
TRex.lore: The undisputed king of dinosaurs, each T-Rex is a veteran of a hundred battles. Their roar alone can shatter glass and stop hearts. Only the bravest handlers dare approach these living weapons. Their teeth are inscribed with runic symbols of power.
TRex.funFact: T-Rexes are surprisingly good at piano, though they can only play two notes at a time. The tower's idle animation sometimes shows them practicing 'Chopsticks'.

Spinosaurus.name: Spinosaurus
Spinosaurus.special: Creates twin acid pools with 35% slow
Spinosaurus.strategy: Superior area control. The twin pool pattern covers more ground than Dilophosaurus. Excellent for defending multiple paths simultaneously.
Spinosaurus.lore: Amphibious predators enhanced with hydro-cannon organs. Their sail-like spine isn't just for temperature regulation - it's a sophisticated targeting system that can track multiple enemies. They're equally deadly on land and in water.
Spinosaurus.funFact: Spinosaurus towers are notorious pranksters who enjoy using their water jets to splash unsuspecting handlers. They seem to find this absolutely hilarious.

Pteranodon.name: Pteranodon
Pteranodon.strategy: Huge range and area damage. Can cover multiple paths from a central position. The aerial attacks ignore terrain obstacles.
Pteranodon.lore: Masters of the sky, these flying fortresses rain destruction from above. Their precision dive-bombing runs are coordinated through ultrasonic echolocation. Each Pteranodon is bonded with its handler through an ancient ritual.
Pteranodon.funFact: Pteranodons have developed a taste for coffee and will often steal cups from the command post. Caffeinated Pteranodons attack 10% faster (not reflected in game stats for balance reasons).

Ankylosaurus.name: Ankylosaurus
Ankylosaurus.special: Ground slam with knockback (42px) and mini-stun (0.25s)
Ankylosaurus.strategy: Defensive powerhouse. The ground slam affects all enemies in range, making it perfect for emergency situations. Place near your base as a last line of defense.
Ankylosaurus.lore: Living tanks with reinforced armor plating and a devastating club tail. Their ground-shaking slams can trigger minor earthquakes. Ancient texts speak of Ankylosaurus formations that could hold mountain passes against entire armies.
Ankylosaurus.funFact: Ankylosaurus towers love belly rubs but are too proud to ask for them. Handlers who figure this out report 15% better combat performance (also not reflected in stats, but totally true).

Quetzalcoatlus.name: Quetzalcoatlus
Quetzalcoatlus.strategy: Strategic global bomber. Use to delete priority threats anywhere on the map. Synergizes with slows to maximize splash efficiency.
Quetzalcoatlus.lore: The colossal sky sovereign casts a shadow that sends troops scattering. Its wings stir gale-force winds as it dives for precision strikes.
Quetzalcoatlus.funFact: Ground crews use signal kites to call in strikes. Quetz sometimes steals the kites for nesting material.

Dreadnoughtus.name: Dreadnoughtus
Dreadnoughtus.strategy: Area denial behemoth. Plant near the base or at choke points to repeatedly juggle clustered enemies.
Dreadnoughtus.lore: Named for its titanic mass, the Dreadnoughtus shakes the ground with every step, shattering formations and nerve alike.
Dreadnoughtus.funFact: Its footfalls double as the campâ€™s drumline. Rhythms improve tower morale by 3â€“5% (anecdotally).
